titleStmt.title: Huon d'Auvergne, Kupferstichkabinett 78 D 8 (olim Hamilton 337) Translation Annotations

notesStmt.note: Brief notes of editorial or codicological nature are contained in a separate .html file
Notes indicating editorial or scribal intervention
Note on interpretation or on literary and historical context.
Notes on the codicological and material state of the manuscript.
Notes that reference other primary sources.
Notes on literal translations where we differ substantially from original

div.note: 1] This is a standard lyric poetry beginning, not usually epic.
175] Gutty gueles, William H. Whitmore, The Elements of Heraldry (Rutland VT: Tuttle, 1968), p. 97.
189] Huon and the king are watching from the castle the battle between the Auvergnats and the king's men. They don't participate at first in the tournament.
210] The expression "les bornes d'Artus" refers to the eastern limits of the known world. See Roman d'Alexandre, Book 1, line 128.

231] If the last word is indeed pis, then it might imply that the king's desire to bring Berart down specifically is ignoble. However, if there is a missing "r" and the word should be "pris" as in T 230, Huon is noticing the king's skill or valor. Does that mean he doesn't think the king needs his help for he soon switches sides.

240] At this point, after Berart's reproach, Huon switches sides and fights alongside the Auvergnats, his men. (In line 140 the king had announced that he wanted Huon on his side, which explains Huon's awkward position. See also lines 221 and 266.)
335]It is clear from line 353 in Laisse 13 that the ladies's processions take place on the the second day of the celebrations.
358] Alternative translation based on se vent coming from "se vanter": [...] which is worth boasting about.

393] A mue is a cage in which a bird is placed while it molts; this could be a reference to the way women were often enclosed in their own apartments for modesty's sake, which is in itself in keeping with the queen's request that men be kept away while she and her ladies participate in the saint's celebrations.

463] Literally: [...] not worth a serviceberry (in MF "alise," variously translated as serviceberry, Juneberry, whitebeam berry). There are many such expressions indicating little value. See also lines 988, 1233, 1703, 2559, 3609, 3911, 4097, 4228, 4827, 5905, 6547, 6780, 7511, 7527, 8041, 8440, 8686, 8768, 9558, 10047, 10066, 10236, 10241, 10617, 10773, 10862, 11611 and 11793.

463] Literally: [...] not worth a serviceberry (in MF "alise," variously translated as serviceberry, Juneberry, whitebeam berry). There are many such expressions indicating little value. See also lines 988, 1233, 1703, 2559, 3609, 3911, 4097, 4228, 4827, 5905, 6547, 6780, 7511, 7527, 8041, 8440, 8686, 8768, 9558, 10047, 10066, 10236, 10241, 10617, 10773, 10862, 11611 and 11793.
494] See DiStefano (Vol. 1, p. 583): "De bon / fort... endroit"
498] Literally: That the king lamented to himself
510] Translation based on understanding conquir as "gagner l'amour de (qn)"; see Matsumura.

571] These two lines are problematic: it isn't clear if sei is from "savoir" or "estre," and it is also not certain if we should understand the king is talking to himself here about harming Huon and his people or if this is the narrator's voice foreshadowing how the king's men will be harmed for they end up in Hell for carrying out Charles's dastardly plans.
638] That is, his fear of her husband.
656] The change from singular to plural, which can sometimes be random in this text or attributable to the rhyme position, may simply be a reference back to "her lord's friends" in line 653 above.
687] Referring to the Devil, Lucifer.
704] The Devil would become Charles's vassal.
791] Translating literally from the text, "a foot," which indicates a small amount.
831] "Leisure" here expresses time available to Huon before he dies. See OED 2b, sub voce, consulted 08/01/2014.
850]Cf. Matsumura "novisme" (which cites FEW7, 212a novus
881] Cf. T 874 which speaks of "soy fradely" ("her brothers").
885] Berart is Huon's cousin, Ynide's cousin by marriage.

927] The word pelegrin (sometimes appearing as peregrin) can also be translated as "stranger" or even "traveler." The miniatures that depict this disguised devil (61R, 63R, 75V) show him in the typical traveling clothes of a medieval pilgrim. However, the hospitality shown him here obeys the Biblical injunction to show hospitality to a stranger, not only pilgrims.
953] Alternative translation lines 952-953: ... for all the gold in a tower, /Indeed he never would have moved one inch toward him
954] Alternative translation: One step along the edge of a tower toward him

994] In this manuscript, vie often means "life" but sometimes means "path" or "route." See for example lines 2498, 8547, 10319, and 10679. Sometimes it is used for word play as in line 1586 where it could mean "life" or "path." Literally: [...] to his path he was obligated.

994] In this manuscript, vie often means "life" but sometimes means "path" or "route." See for example lines 2498, 8547, 10319, and 10679. Sometimes it is used for word play as in line 1586 where it could mean "life" or "path." Literally: [...] to his path he was obligated.
1034] Lines 1033 and 1034 have been reversed in the translation for clarity.
1094] From the Distichs of Cato, see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Distichs_of_Cato.
1125] At the time, "frère" meant not only "brother" but also was a term of affection; see line 790 above when Charles Martel calls Huon "frère."
1174] Psalm 118.133: Keep steady my steps according to thy promise [...]
1215] Alternative translation for lines 1214-1215: I will not be recreant in obeying what he sent me to do even unto death [Cf. Chrétien de Troyes, Erec et Enide line 2462]
1233] Literally: [...] that isn't worth chervil
1240] Literally: On whose neck in front of him he put the bridle
1260] Literally: Do you want this, son? [...]
1380] In F-I boce means "chest."
1326] Literally: [...] without bad circumstances

1378] Could this possibly be a reference to or confusion with Cilicia, a pagan land? See Moisan, Répertoire des noms propres, Tome II Volume 3 (Droz: 1986), p. 872. On the other hand, Huon's next stop is Calabria, so Sicily is more likely the translation.
1380] In this context voir can't be translated as "truth" which is its most primary meaning.
1390] See the original for explanation.
1421] That is, piracy against those they happen upon.
1467] That is, because of his supposed madness.
1586] Possible play on words: "via/vita" in Italian, or "vie/voie" in French.
1630] There seems to be a confusion here between "tordre" and "torner." Cf. T 1630: in altro afare ti mete che te torne a onore
1703] Literally: That they wouldn't surrender for the worth of a spur
1734] Literally: There where you will die, we ourselves will never return [Perhaps analogous to Ruth 1.17: "where you die I will die, and there will I be buried"]
1773] The narrator is impressed with how well the men following Huon's example fight despite their fear.
1815] Huon must be referring to recovering the banner of one of the freed prisoners. See note to line 1845 about standards in battle.

1845] In addition to standards or banners carried into battle (see lines 1748 ff.), a standard might be placed in a camp in a temporary position, usually outside the tent of a commander, and not be carried onto the battlefield. It would also mark the place where commanders would gather to go over strategy and battle plans. Thus it would indicate a gathering spot. (Thanks to Dr. Kelly DeVries, personal communication, 14 May 2021.).
1898] Literally: The nobleman wept much from the eyes in his face

1909] Mantenir, which applies to two direct objects, God and the people, has the sense of both “uphold” and “protect,” the first sense applying more to God and the second sense applying more to the people. Thus the verb occurs twice in the translation.

1942] The translation of gesir is more literally "situation" or "manière d'être" but Huon is clearly referring to his mission. Thanks for Jean-Claude Vallecalle for his consultation on this point (24 May 2021).
1961] corner l'aigue = announce the time to wash one's hands before a meal (Hindley); see also TL column 876, lines 14-20.
1989] Literally: [...] if famine did not reach them

2090] The placement of quotation marks in these two lines of the translation doesn't match the transcription. The transition from narration to quotation isn't always clear in the text and the beginning and end of the quotation in the translation was adjusted for purposes of flow.
2117] Spirital here seems to indicate "not of this earth," contrasted with the terre of the previous line; that is, Hell is not to be found on earth.
2129] The translation of forer is based on "forrier" ("soldat qui va au fourrage" in Matsumura); however, cf. T 2121: et li forestery che con·uy sono recolty
2138] Huon is praising the suggestion to choose someone else to be king of Jerusalem.
2208] Literally: [...] whom you drew from his side

2235] This part of Huon's prayer (through line 2245) resembles the contemporary Universal Prayer (or Prayer of the Faithful), the part of the mass in which the priest lists things to pray for ("intentions") and the faithful respond "Lord, hear our prayer" after each item. See https://www.usccb.org/prayer-and-worship/the-mass/order-of-mass/liturgy-of-the-word/universal-prayer. Huon, of course, receives an immediate response from God by means of the letter brought by the dove.
2259] Literally: [...] the day was at nones
2268] This seems to refer to the candle in line 2254 and the revelation of who is to be king.
2285] Literally: Put into your hearing and heart this true tale
2396] Cf. T 2422: p[er]zò Dio li dona forza e natura francha"; perhaps stoie < "estout" which would give an alternative translation of "bold nature"
2404] Alternative translation: [...] that he doesn't suffer for faith (penoie < OF "pener" which can mean "make an effort" or "suffer")
2418] çausir: see Holtus Lexikalisches, p. 248, çausi.
2445] This seems to refer to Samson who is opposed to abandoning Huon. See Laisse 136 where they find each other again.
2492] Ironic comment referring to the greater robbers they would meet (see line 2494).
2508] Meaning that he was generally unconcerned with his physical well-being.
2568] Cf. line 7644 for similar language.

2591] maroy here seems to be related to some dialectical words in Italian that mean "large stone"; see Pellegrini 1968 "marògna" and Basso 2000 "marogna" and "marògnola." See other instances at lines 2702, 2890, 7283, 7831 and 8097 (where it is spelled marois). In all instances the corresponding line in Turin has some variation of "preda" or "predon" ("stone" related to OF "perron").
2596] Literally: [...] I don't know how to equip myself (Cf. T 2578).

2632] Cf. T 2614: De cossa che me dovesse s[er]vire a piaquimento. Turin also understands plaquiment as coming from "piacere" ("piacimento" DELI p. 1182; 'piacere' = "pleasure" [before 1249, Pier della Vigna])
2637] pietosement can be translated either "piously" or "piteously"; context does not always make it clear.
2759] The original audience of this text would not have considered her unconsummated pagan marriage legitimate.

2795] This idea of holding each other (“relever des fonz” / “tenir sur les fonz” are technical terms relating to baptism) refers to the two ladies standing godparent to each other, not strictly in keeping with ecclesiastical law, particularly so because when the servant raises her mistress from the baptismal waters she is still not baptized herself. Of course, they are being baptized in sea water in this passage, not at a baptismal font as mentioned in the usual terminology. Thanks to PEB for this clarification on baptism.
2814] Literally: [...] To be cheered up now
2825] Huon seems to be saying that the apparent poor quality of what is available to eat will make them strong because of their new faith in God.
2854] See "Additional Notes" for information about staff weapons (or pole arms) of the time, which is the category to which the bill and the guisarme (our understanding of guie) belong.
2862] Probable reference to his blonde wife Ynide.
2904] Literally: [...] it was fitting to them to be paid
2935] See line 2854 for explanation of "bill." See also line 2946 below.
2949] Literally: It was three large measures long [...] (This measure, toise, equals about six feet.)
2950] Literally: And in the width of the body there was more than one part [of a toise]; according to PEB, "one part" indicates "one half," thus "three feet."
2957] Literally: [...] that buys everything
3004] "Generous Giver" is an epithet for God.
3015] fire is one of the possible forms of the present subjunctive of "ferir" which gives the present translation. See note in the transcription for this line for other possibilities.
3076] Alternative translation based on understanding s'aseöri as coming from "s'asseürer" : [...] he had never been so protected / For he had never been guarded in this way.
3088] Huon seems to be saying that he will leave some of the heavy fighting to the lion.
3171] Lines 3168-71 have been reordered for clarity.

3215] The word çap seems to indicate "zap(pa)", so dig by dig; "zappa" and "zappare" appear in Italian before 1294 (DELI); "çapare" (Stussi, beg. Thirteenth century, Guida ai dialetti veneti, cited DELI, p. 1847). Literally, "une schielle" is 'a ladder'.
3220] The word sol here could indicate that the serpent is spread out sunning itself.
3249] Literally: [...] his flesh brother (meaning, his human brother)

3284] See T: 3244 A la vose ch'el fasea, pare ch'el dica sermone. The Berlin manuscript appears to be missing a verb which occurs in the Turin manuscript, without which the translation doesn't make sense.
3318] Psalms 26 and 119, actually: Legem pone [mihi] domine
3320] Psalm 100: [Jubilate] Deo, omnis terra
3336] The verb asenere seems to come from "assennare."
3354] Here Huon addresses the figure aloud.
3365] Literally: [...] and be in great heat/burning

3385] The word xais is translated 'stone' since line 3283 states that the devil/hermit condemned to a stone (perons). See T 3344: intro in gran saso me serà quy un prodomo. See Alexandre de Paris. Le Roman d'Alexandre. Trans. Laurence Harf-Lancner. Ed. E. C. Armstrong. Paris : Lettres gothiques (Le Livre de poche), 1976. Laisse 160, lines 2808-2819. Cf. Lat. SAXUM, 'sasso' in Modern Italian.
3396] Literally: He besieges your land around and about

3420] Huon, of course, is seeking the Devil, Lucifer himself, but the trapped devil seems almost to be playing with him. An alternative translation might yet be: You seek the Devil, you can find him right here
3460] Literally: Then there will be quickly gotten for us the best [thing]
3468] Could this mean "on the side of the mountain"?.
3487] Literally: [...] the field, they emptied it
3504] Presumably not a stepsister or sister-in-law of some sort.

3513] It is unclear from the original whether everything is "his" or "hers" owing to the agreement of adjectives in Romance languages (including the possessive) with the noun they modify. The translation is based on the idea that if everything is the sister's, it is also his through his marriage to her.
3530] Literally: If you are right [...]
3532] Literally: [...] then he took her by the finger
3553] Cf. T 3513; B seems to be using a construction similar to "farcela" in MSI.
3561] It is possible that the verbs in this line are second person singular which would give an alternative translation: You will do justice just as you must (cf. T 3521).
3563] Literally: If you are right, right will be with you
3566] If the punctuation were the following: Je suy enci. Por li, or dites que sera, then the translation would read: "I am here. As for her, tell me now what will be." Cf. T 3523.
3591] Literally: so that by lack I not have the wrong
3958] Literally: The lady was dispersed/scattered along with her lord; perhaps a reference to the ashes of their burned bodies being scattered and dispersed by the wind.
3688] That is, Huon would kill them all and send them to God's judgment.
3723] Literally: [...] we'll be in holy mercy

3728] Miserere from Psalm 50 (51), "Have mercy on me, O God" (also the beginning of Psalms 55 and 56). According to the First Advent encyclopedia, "It is the first psalm at Lauds in all the ferial (week-day) Offices throughout the year". For further details, see Hugh Henry, "Miserere," The Catholic Encyclopedia. Vol. 10 (New York: Robert Appleton Company, 1911, consulted 28 Oct. 2014, http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/10352c.htm>).
3753] Despite their abandonment of Huon, he came through the experience uninjured. Thus they are guilty, but he forgives them.
3788] l'en = "l'on" (translated as "everyone")
3792] There seems to be a switch of subjects here without specifying names.
3801] Literally: Who would sacrifice God's person [in the Eucharist]
3849] As opposed to the "porte marine" (the sea gate)
3851] The deschacimant or "expulsion" has not yet taken place. The dispute is over the town's inhabitants desire for a "commune," that is, a free town without an overlord.
3914] Literally: If you wish to be such [...] (rearrangement of these two lines for clarity)
3983] Literally: [...] he had a good heart toward Him
4020] Cf. T 3981 ynnanzo voleno a onore morire che esere afamà
4024] Alternative translation: The battalions having been formed, they advanced to strike them.
4052] As in other passages, the text alternates between singular and plural without clarifying who is meant. Here luy could be the lion or could be Huon.

4056] As happens so often in this text, singular and plural forms are mixed up leading to a lack of clarity. However, the miniature at the bottom of the folio page shows the lion in battle along with the knights.
4070] The term croupon is a technical term for a horse's hindquarters.
4071] Could cors mean "horn"? Is this marvelous horse a unicorn?
4099] Literally: [...] you won't be fallen
4159] Cf. T 4116: El ne poria ben y[n]sire male asay.
4164] Literally: [...] as a well-bred man
4204] NOTE Cf. lines 8329 and 8529 for similar references to the opening of Psalm 133.

4206] This negative rendering of the "Golden Rule" is attributed to Rabbi Hillel in the Babylonian Talmud, Shabbath folio 31a, but various forms of the "Golden Rule" exist in both positive and negative forms (do unto others, etc.) in many cultures from many periods.
4228] Literally: [...] worth the price of chervil to him
4229] Here the en is "on" [=one]

4254] This entire section is confusing in that the young man doesn’t identify the people on the ship as merchants until line 4275 in the next laisse. However, in T 4211-4214, there is specific mention of sailors on the ship. Thus the words in the square brackets were added for clarity.

4263] This appears to be a flashback of how the merchants from Prester John’s land arrived at and quickly left Cappadocia owing to the conflict going on. For that reason, they do not know how the war turned out, unlike Huon who Christianized the people and himself set up Samson as ruler, as he recounts below in lines 4293ff.
4264] The double negative is confusing and doesn't exist in Turin.
4269] Literally: [...] for I will truly reassure you
4283] Literally: [...] the one of Moses
4294] Literally: It was Cappadocia [...]

4299] The verb "conserver" takes a direct object. In OF "li" is singular as an indirect object, but in Italian it is the third-person plural direct object. Thus Italian usage seems to be dominant in this instance. Cf. Mascipelli, La Geste francor nel cod. marc. V13., p. 294.
4358] Literally: [...] to my knowledge

4360] This could be a reference to Matthew 7.14: For the gate is narrow and the way is hard, that leads to life and those who find it are few. If so, the text would be transcribed: Stroite ert la voie qui no l'atient a tant and the translation would read: "The way is narrow for the one who doesn't seize it right away."
4372] Literally: That might well be proven to me to be false

4398] It would seem that the scribe didn't understand the source manuscript. The sense in this line is out of step with the rest of the passage that never seems to describe negative reactions to the merchants.
4399] The lack of subject nouns leads to confusion. We have added subjects that seem reasonable from the context for clarification.
4403] This is an extremely difficult passage, requiring one of our rare emendations to make sense.

4437] Is Prester John being referred to here as an urbanite or a commoner? He must be the person mentioned since he is referred to in the next line. The word petit could mean small of stature or perhaps refer to unassuming dress as compared to all the nobles in the church. In any case, not only does he not appear smaller in the illumination at the bottom of folio 31r which shows Huon on his knees; rather he is the largest figure in the miniature as befits his importance.
4467] Literally: [...] God's armor
4514] The verb roeler means "torture" or "break on the wheel."
4515] Literally: [...] his soul, it is damned
4563] See note at line 1961.
4604] Literally: That is not him [...]
4612] The reference to the month in the next line implies that the narrator is speaking of feudal service.
4633] Literally: When Prester John saw that it will do nothing
4661] Literally: He prayed often to God [...]

4707] Tholomé (in French but Ptolemy in English) is also the name of one of Alexander the Great’s most trusted men, one of his “douze pers” (Ptolémée). See Branche 1, Laisse 31, for the choice of the peers. Cf. line 4745 where the reference is actually to Alexander's companion and not this vassal of Charles's court.
4716] This seems to be a kind of shorthand to express the sense that honor and dishonor are the most important considerations in deciding how to live.
4741] Alternative translation: [...] because he shows them love

4743] This use of senator implies one who serves the Emperor of the Holy Roman Empire. See John Watts, The Making of Polities: Europe, 1300-1500: "In 1239 he [Frederick II] appealed to the cardinals as Senators of Rome, calling on them to convoke a general council of the Church at which the issues in play between himself and the pope could be judged" (p. 58). Cf. Roland's title in the Entrée d'Espagne.

4745] The archbishop appears to be comparing Charles to Ptolemy I Soter, the companion of Alexander the Great, who later became emperor of Egypt, establishing the dynasty that included Cleopatra. It would not be logical for the archbishop to speak here of Duke Tholomeus.
4758] Ranse: rhyme creation for "rose."
4783] Common metaphor for inspiring love
4788] A possible filling out of these two lines might be: It would be impossible [to imagine]/ That a lady not [give in]
4792] This line follows the general form of proverbial declarations but it could be translated alternatively: These men left in joy and came back in sorrow
4795] Literally: [...] richly loaded
4846] Entrée d'Espagne, torqier, torquer, torchier "litière"? Infurna gives "strame" (hay, straw) as the translation in his volume.-->
4860] This character is not mentioned earlier in the list of ambassadors, lines 4702-4710.

4932] vers trova: translation based on understanding vers as "direction" in an Italian usage; DELI for example, gives Petrarch 1374 "mutare verso" as 'change direction', as well as similar constructions of the same era. However, vers could mean "verse," giving the alternative translation: For a long time just as the poem says
4956] Langlois: Carsie is a variant of Tarsie (133)
4958] Cf. T 4796: lo maro pasarano sopra lo re mescredente
4962] Literally: Concerning that the count made an angry face

4976] A tree of virtues was often juxtaposed with a tree of vices in the medieval Christian tradition, each tree showing the relationships among qualities. Cf. T brazo de yustizia, et ombra de vertude (shadow of virtue)

5048] Guineste is Winchester. See Flutre, Louis-Fernand. Table des noms propres avec toutes leurs variantes figurant dans les romans du moyen âge écrits en francais ou en provencal et actuellement publiés ou analysés. Poitiers: Centre d'études supérieures de civilisation médiévale, 1962, p. 249.
5070] Not clear if the pronoun refers to "her lord" or to the honor just mentioned. Ynide's response seems to indicate she understood it as referring to Huon.
5071] Literally: [...] you are lying through your throat
5072] Literally: [...] more than the eyes in my face
5155] Literally: 'It's right to slap someone who gets worked up.' (Translation in text thanks to PEB. We have not found this saying in any dictionary of proverbs.)
5160] He seems to be threatening Ynide here with the possibility of the king coming to attack her lands for her disobedience of his orders.

5172] Alternative translation: [...] you have me greatly under constraint (based on alternative punctuation: [...] formans m'avés l'astrine and understanding astrine as deriving from the verb "astreindre" instead of from "estriner")

5178] The present translation is in keeping with what follows in the text, but chue could be from "ciu" ("blind" T-L col. 27-28) and guercine could be from "guercio" (=strabico/ cross-eyed, DELI early 14th c.), giving an alternative translation: [...] was neither blind nor cross-eyed
5182] This might be Antwerp, Anvers in French, Anversa in Italian.
5242] Could this be a reference to Eve?
5245] Literally: From wanting to repent it would be too great a delay (the implication being that any delay, even the brief one from desire to repent to actual repentance, would be too long)

5289] An alternative translation is possible if the transcription is punctuated differently. Le rois de Franse, qe ci nos oit envoiés,/ De voloir plans qe soiés honorés?/ E ou se puet gregno[r] hono[r]s avoir trovés/ Cu[m] le rois obeir e fer sa volontés? The king of France, why has he sent us here,/ Truly desirous that you be honored?/ And where can greater honor be found/ Than by obeying the king and doing his will?

5327] Cf. 1 Kings 6.29-30: He carved all the walls of the house round about with carved figures of cherubim and palm trees and open flowers, in the inner and outer rooms. The floor of the house he overlaid with gold in the inner and outer rooms.

5336] Translation based on T 5191: eio vezo cristianità y[n] gran [con]fusione. Could construcions actually be constriicions in MS, thus "constraint" or "constriction"? In any case, it has to be a negative or problematic outlook which upsets Ynide.

5361] Translation based on a transcription that scans as only 9 syllables: Se, si cum moy, m'avés coneüe. Another possibility is Se si cum m'oÿ m'avés coneüe (which scans as 10 syllables): If you had known me as you heard me [tell you I was]
5399] If estamelle is related to "estamine" (=tool), this could be a reference to the punishment meted out to an adultress.
5464] Literally: [...] distinguish the white from the indigo
5466] Literally: [...] sighed from her heart
5482] Literally: And those to whom there is the most [...]
5519] Literally: [...] I have refused my consent to you
5528] Owing to its rhyme position, "piler" has been shortened to pir.
5537] Literally: [...] badly satisfied. Alternative translation: [...] you make him appear ill
5537] Literally: [...] badly satisfied. Alternative translation: [...] you make him appear ill
5560] Literally: [...] What is this that you have said?
5573] Literally: [...] by the eyes with which I see
5574] This has the cadence of a proverb or saying. Literally: [...] it is [just] wind that huffs and puffs
5574] This has the cadence of a proverb or saying. Literally: [...] it is [just] wind that huffs and puffs
5585] Alternative transcription based on por mains and cobré understood as coming from "combrer": Saudin and Roger took each other by the hand
5602] Translation is based on understanding aubré < "ovrer" and raissé < "rasseoir"
5637] Alternative translation: And she [Generosity?] embraces him, but has not corrupted him
5646] The word caume means "psalm," but the relevant line sounds more like a proverb.

5660] Psalm 40.11: Tu autem Domine miserere mei et resuscita me et retribuam eis (But thou, O Lord, have mercy on me, and raise me up again: and I will requite them). Or it could be: Tu autem Domine miserere nobis (But Thou, O Lord, have mercy upon us), a phrase said at the end of biblical readings in the liturgy of the medieval church.
5666]cors could mean "heart" or "body," so there may be a double entendre in play here.
5669] Literally: [...] I am not such a youth
5677] Literally: Everyone stayed bent over under his hat

5681] Literally: This is the heart enclosed under such cloth (The meaning is unclear, either referring to the king's heart covered by his royal robes, or to Saudin having the treasures, which represent the irresistible passion of the king for Ynide, hidden under his mantle; see lines 5662-63)
5697] Cf. T 5472: Ora l'alta sezia desopra, la raina sederite (could this be a reference to the high position on the Wheel of Fortune?)
5724] "The one who is prized" seems to be a reference to Huon.

7004] Bucephalus is the name of Alexander's horse. Huon's horse was previously compared to Bucephalus, now he is called by his name metaphorically, essentially a way of calling him an excellent horse.

7006] Baldras: name found both for persons and places in medieval texts. There is a modern Baudre in northern France, in the St-Lô area (Langlois). In epic texts, Baudas is a Saracen city, originally Baghdad (Moisan, v. 2: 1052-53. Like names in many medieval texts, any association with a specific place is entirely speculative and more so when the name is in the rhyme position.

8891] Famous pagan giants or gigantic figures. Marsile (Ital. Marsilio) is a pagan king, opponent of Charlemagne and Roland in the Song of Roland, son of Galafre (Ital. Galafro), and also appears in numerous late poems. Danebron (Danebruno), also a Saracen, appears in Aspramonte. Goliath is a biblical character (1 Sam 17; 2 Sam 19), defeated by David or by Elhanan depending upon the tradition. Agolant (Agolante) is the Saracen king of Africa; in Aspramonte he is defeated at Reggio. Helmont (Almonte, Eaumont) is the son of Agolant who appoints him to be king of France; he was the original owner of Durendal (Durlindana) and is also defeated in Aspramonte.
8919] Traditional location for the Final Judgment.
8922] Alternative translation: Then it will be obvious who has taken a good path (cf. T 8592: alora parerà che abia bona via usata; see also Matthew 7.13)
8922] Alternative translation: Then it will be obvious who has taken a good path (cf. T 8592: alora parerà che abia bona via usata; see also Matthew 7.13)
8928] This is the version in the Roman de Troie.
8953] This seems to refer to the sanctity of a vow taken on relics.

8966] Huon is worried about a possible betrayal and draws an analogy with Antenor's actions in the Old French Roman de Troie. In classical tradition Antenor was a Trojan lord and companion of Aeneas. But the Old French Roman de Troie tradition shows Antenor as a traitor who helps the Greeks take the city (cf. Dante's Inferno 32.88: the second section of the ninth circle of Hell is named after him). Traditionally, Antenor is also the founder of the city of Padua; one can see his tomb there (https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/tomb-of-antenor). Roman de Troie, lines 24729 ff., pp. 587-end; plot begins specifically pp. 588-89 (Baumgartner and Vielliard, ed. 1998).
8969] Alternative translation: For not daring to come with you

8985] In some medieval renderings, Aeneas’s flight from Troy with his possessions and family is tinged with treason. See Guido delle Colonne's 13th-century account in Latin. Griffin, N. E., ed., Guido delle Colonne, Historia destructionis Troiae, Medieval Academy Books 26 (Cambridge: 1936) pp. 218, 234.
8996] Literally: [...] this weeping comes from childhood
9000] The "lesser guide" is the Sibyl who led Aeneas to his father to ask about his future. Aeneid, Book 6.
9014] Alternative translation: Long stature, one and a half toise (A 'toise' was a unit of measure equal to about six feet; see Hindley).
9022] Cf. T 8693-8695. Lines 9022-9024 could be directed at William which would explain why the verb veut in 9022 is in the third person.
9028] Another reference to Lucifer.
9035] Literally: For he carried no flesh or bone at all

9053] In his old age, William of Orange sought to build a bridge to shorten the pilgrimage route to Santiago de Compostela. The story appears in the Moniage Guillaume II; see Bennett, "Guillaume d'Orange."

9294] Patarenes were heretics in the Milan area in the eleventh century, the name comes from the dialect word for rags. They supported the movements against simony and nicolaitism. However, the name came to mean heretics in general, and sometimes Cathars, followers of a type of Manichaeism.

9305] The Alamanni were a Germanic tribe that once occupied the location of modern Alsace and part of Switzerland. They were conquered by Clovis around 496 CE. The Teutons were a Germanic people identified in classical writings as living in what is now Scandinavia. They fought alongside other Germanic tribes against the expanding Roman republic and were defeated in the late second century BCE.

9713] Dares the Phrygian and Dictys the Cretan retold the Trojan War, opposing Virgil's point of view, making Aeneas a traitor. For a brief introduction to how this comes through in medieval Italian literature, see Valentina Prosperi's article, "Virgilian Katabasis and Trojan Genealogy in Early Modern Italian Poetry” (Maia 65.3, 2013, pp. 583-96), available at http://www.academia.edu/4920420/Virgilian_Katabasis_and_Trojan_Genealogy_in_Early_Modern_Italian_Poetry; they are largely the reason for many revisionist views of the Trojan War during the Middle Ages, which are in opposition to Dante's view (and thus would promote Huon's refusing Aeneas as guide).

9946] This is a problematic line. An alternative translation could be: That people call Nicomacus. However, why would a gate be called Nicomacus when in the previous laisse, Nicomacus appears as a soul in Hell? On the other hand, who is calling Nicomacus by name? Is it Farabus, the character explained by Aeneas in this laisse and the next? It isn't clear. T is quite similar to B, thus presenting the same problem. Br and P are different, each speaking of the scholars surrounding Nicomacus coming through the gate.

10206] Girart de Fraite: one of Charlemagne’s vassals who refuses to obey him. In Aspremont, the Old French chanson de geste, the Franco-Italian versions, and Andrea da Barberino’s Aspramonte, he refuses to come to Charles’s aid in southern Italy against a Saracen invasion. When he does come, finally, he rescues the French army. However, he continues to refuse to render homage to Charlemagne, so Charlemagne goes into his territory to besiege him; Charles wins, and Girart dies in a dungeon. Girart is therefore the epitome of a rebel baron refusing Charlemagne’s kingship. Aspremont was extremely popular in Italy. See the website, http://www.chansondaspremont.eu/ for an ongoing project to edit the entire range of manuscripts.
